definition: gate/door/CL:扇[shan4]/gateway/doorway/CL:個|个[ge4]/opening/valve/switch/way to do something/knack/family/house/(religious) sect/school (of thought)/class/category/phylum or division (taxonomy)/classifier for large guns/classifier for lessons, subjects, branches of technology/(suffix) -gate (i.e. scandal; derived from Watergate)

sentences.english: Thoughts are visitors, who visit the central station of the mind.
sentences.chinese: 想法是來大腦中央站點串門的門客。

sentences.english: They strive for perfection and will expect the same from you.
sentences.chinese: 他們可是追求完善的門客。

sentences.english: Gong was very satisfied with the new follower.
sentences.chinese: 公孫龍對這個新收的門客非常滿意。

sentences.english: Nor can South Korea expect China to rein in its North Korean client.
sentences.chinese: 同時，韓國也無法指望中國約束這位朝鮮“門客”。

sentences.english: He is just one of the Warring States Period Zhao Ping Yuanjun Menke.
sentences.chinese: 他只不過是戰國時期趙國平原君的一位門客。

sentences.english: Not long afterwards, Gongsun and his followers went on a journey.
sentences.chinese: 沒過多久，公孫龍和他的門客一起出外遊玩。

sentences.english: There is a sacrifice to the chu and rewarded MenKe a pot of wine.
sentences.chinese: 楚國有個祭祀的人，賞給門客一壺酒。

sentences.english: Some days later, Gongsun Long and his followers went on a trip.
sentences.chinese: 沒過多久，公孫龍和他的門客一起出外遊玩。

sentences.english: Among these retainers, they are from every social stratum, and they have all kind of experience.
sentences.chinese: 這麼多門客之中，各個階層，各種經歷的人都有。

sentences.english: In the state of Chu there was a man who was sacrificing to his ancestors;
sentences.chinese: 楚國有個祭祀的人，他賜給他的門客一杯酒。

definition: Li Guang (-119 BC), Han dynasty general, nicknamed Flying General 飛將軍|飞将军 and much feared by the Xiongnu 匈奴
to denounce/to condemn/to call to account/to punish
armed enemy of the nation/enemy of the Emperor/fig. championship challenger/contender opposing champion in sporting contest
to open a law court/to set up a mourning hall
"Strategies of the Warring States", chronicle of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC), possibly written by Su Qin 蘇秦|苏秦[Su1 Qin2]
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
commander-in-chief, the equivalent of king in Chinese chess
